ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Programming language C, C++, logical thinking skills. Also the use of Arduino.
I mastered the basics of C programming, built a stronger understanding of problem-solving, and got an introduction to a wide range of applications of Arduino programming.
I learned about coding in C as well as coding in Arduino IDE. From Arduino we got a brief look at the hardware side of coding.
Skills on C programming and Arduino circuit designing. And the professor has attached importance on the ability of problem solving.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strengths are the professor is very nice and able to present logically and explain things clearly. 
The weakness is that the course is just a introduction course, and the course is too short.

The first section of this coursewhich focused on C programmingwas fantastic. Super well-organized and engaging. The Arduino part, while still super fascinating, felt like it could have benefitted from a longer course. Maybe some adjustments could have been made to fit the subject matter to a smaller time frame.

The course got through a lot of material, however maybe not as efficient or quickly as possible. The pace was rather slow maybe to not lose people who are not as comfortable for technology but I felt it dragged on at times.

The course had a clear syllabus and adequate materials. However, it was hard to cover all the basic things of C programming and Arduino. In fact, it took too long time to inform the basic things which could be learned on the own, and lectures assigned to Arduino was cut down. I suggest that this course be more direct to a clear aim, such as focusing on either C or Arduino.
Very difficult to teach CS that involves hardware virtually in an engaging way. I would have preferred to learn MATLAB as was taught in the past

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, for students that are interested in programming but do not have prior experience in it.

Yes! It's a great course for anyone across the "beginner" range of skill level with coding: for those who've had an introduction, it's a nice brush-up and opportunity to engage more deeply, and for those with no experience, it's a good first exposure.
I think for an intro coding class it did its job effectively. It was slow at times but overall manageable. Overall, I would recommend it as it would help you decide if coding is for you.
Yes. Any student who is interested in computing and or electrical engineering but has not had much experience with them would benefit from this class.

Perhaps I would recommend it to students that don't major in computer science but somehow interested in it for an overall experience on programming. But for those major in engineering, they may need more specialized course.
